item.name: CPU Load Average last minute
item.description: CPU Load Average on Baracuda NG Firewalls over the last minute.

item.name: CPU Load Average last 5 minutes
item.description: CPU Load Average on Baracuda NG Firewalls over the last minute.

trigger.name: CPU Load Average too high
trigger.description: Triggers if the CPU Load Average over the last 5 minutes is to high for this hardware model. Because number of cores cannot be determined trough SNMP the value has to be overwritten on the host level. Default {$TOTALCPUCORES} definde in this template is 1.

item.name: CPU Load Average last 15 minutes
item.description: CPU Load Average on Baracuda NG Firewalls over the last minute.

template.template: Template Barracuda NG Firewall SNMP HA - for inactive members
template.name: Template Barracuda NG Firewall SNMP HA

trigger_prototype.name: Service {#SNMPVALUE} running on HA node
trigger_prototype.description: Service should not run on HA slave node

template.template: Template Barracuda NG Firewall SNMP without VPN
template.name: Template Barracuda NG Firewall SNMP without VPN

discovery_rule.name: Disk partitions
discovery_rule.description:
The rule will discover all disk partitions matching the global regexp "Storage devices for SNMP discovery".
{$SNMP_COMMUNITY} is a global macro.

item_prototype.name: Allocation units for storage $1
item_prototype.description: The size, in bytes, of the data objects allocated from this pool. If this entry is monitoring sectors, blocks, buffers, or packets, for example, this number will commonly be greater than one. Otherwise this number will typically be one.

item_prototype.name: Description of storage $1
item_prototype.description: A description of the type and instance of the storage described by this entry.

item_prototype.name: Total disk space on $1
item_prototype.description: This is a calculated item, we need it to get total disk space in bytes.

item_prototype.name: Total disk space on $1 in units
item_prototype.description: The size of the storage represented by this entry, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits. This object is writable to allow remote configuration of the size of the storage area in those cases where such an operation makes sense and is possible on the underlying system. For example, the amount of main memory allocated to a buffer pool might be modified or the amount of disk space allocated to virtual memory might be modified.

item_prototype.name: Used disk space on $1
item_prototype.description: This is a calculated item, we need it to get used disk space in bytes.

item_prototype.name: Used disk space on $1 in units
item_prototype.description: The amount of the storage represented by this entry that is allocated, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits.

trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than 20% on volume {#SNMPVALUE}

item.name: Device contact details
item.description: The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person. If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Device description
item.description: A textual description of the entity. This value should include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and networking software.

item.name: Device location
item.description: The physical location of this node (e.g., `telephone closet, 3rd floor'). If the location is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Device name
item.description: An administratively-assigned name for this managed node. By convention, this is the node's fully-qualified domain name. If the name is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Device uptime
item.description: The time since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

item.name: Number of network interfaces
item.description: The number of network interfaces (regardless of their current state) present on this system.

discovery_rule.name: Network interfaces
discovery_rule.description:
You may also consider using IF-MIB::ifType or IF-MIB::ifAlias for discovery depending on your filtering needs.
{$SNMP_COMMUNITY} is a global macro.

item_prototype.name: Admin status of interface $1
item_prototype.description: The desired state of the interface.

item_prototype.name: Description of interface $1
item_prototype.description: A textual string containing information about the interface. This string should include the name of the manufacturer, the product name and the version of the interface hardware/software.

item_prototype.name: Inbound errors on interface $1
item_prototype.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.

item_prototype.name: Incoming traffic on interface $1
item_prototype.description: The number of octets in valid MAC frames received on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

item_prototype.name: Operational status of interface $1
item_prototype.description: The current operational state of the interface.

trigger_prototype.name: Operational status was changed on {HOST.NAME} interface {#SNMPVALUE}

item_prototype.name: Outbound errors on interface $1
item_prototype.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that could not be transmitted because of errors.

item_prototype.name: Outgoing traffic on interface $1
item_prototype.description: The number of octets transmitted in MAC frames on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

item_prototype.name: Utilization of processor #$1
item_prototype.description: The average, over the last minute, of the percentage of time that this processor was not idle. Implementations may approximate this one minute smoothing period if necessary.
